article.title: The effect of spaceflight on the gravity-sensing auxin gradient of roots: GFP reporter gene microscopy on orbit
article.abstract: Our primary aim was to determine whether gravity has a direct role in establishing the auxin-mediated gravity-sensing system in primary roots.

sections.introduction: Since the times of the Darwinsâ€™ treatise on the power of movement in plants1 and the experiments of Cholodny and Went2 gravity has been established as central to many patterns of plant development.
sections.methods: The data presented here are taken from two independent experiments launched to the ISS.
sections.results: The distribution of DR5r::GFP in the roots of plants grown on the ISS was identical to that of the ground controls over the course of the two ISS experiments, several plant ages, and varied root morphologies.
sections.discussion: The plants examined here were derived from two distinct spaceflight experiments.

article.insights_summary: The distribution of auxin in the gravity-sensing portion of the root is not dependent on gravity. Spaceflight appears benign to auxin and its role in the development of the primary root tip, whereas spaceflight may influence cytokinin-associated processes.
